title-group.article-title: Efficient Rehabilitation Care for Joint Replacement Patients
title-group.subtitle: Skilled Nursing Facility or Inpatient Rehabilitation Facility?

article-meta.aff: National Rehabilitation Hospital, Washington, DC (WT, GD, C-HH)
Institute for Clinical Outcome Research, Salt Lake City, Utah (SDH)
Lewin Group and Dobson/DaVanzo, Vienna, Virginia (JED)

author-notes.corresp: Wenqiang Tian, National Rehabilitation Hospital, 102 Irving Street NW, Washington, DC 20010; e-mail: wenqiang.tian@medstar.net.

abstract.p: Objective. There has been lengthy debate as to which setting, skilled nursing facility (SNF) or inpatient rehabilitation facility (IRF), is more efficient in treating joint replacement patients. This study aims to determine the efficiency of rehabilitation care provided by SNF and IRF to joint replacement patients with respect to both payment and length of stay (LOS). Methods. This study used a prospective multisite observational cohort design. Tobit models were used to examine the association between setting of care and efficiency. The study enrolled 948 knee replacement patients and 618 hip replacement patients from 11 IRFs and 7 SNFs between February 2006 and February 2007. Output was measured by motor functional independence measure (FIM) score at discharge. Efficiency was measured in 3 ways: payment efficiency, LOS efficiency, and stochastic frontier analysis efficiency. Results. IRF patients incurred higher expenditures per case but also achieved larger motor FIM gains in shorter LOS than did SNF patients. Setting of care was not a strong predictor of overall efficiency of rehabilitation care. Great variation in characteristics existed within IRFs or SNFs and severity groups. Medium-volume facilities among both SNFs and IRFs were most efficient. Early rehabilitation was consistently predictive of efficient treatment. Conclusions. The advantage of either setting is not clear-cut. Definition of efficiency depends in part on preference between cost and time. SNFs are more payment efficient; IRFs are more LOS efficient. Variation within SNFs and IRFs blurred setting differences; a simple comparison between SNF and IRF may not be appropriate.

body.p: Over the past 15 years, the number of hip and knee replacements in the United States has increased dramatically, whereas lengths of stay in acute care have decreased markedly. This in turn has led to a growth in post–acute care for patients with recent joint replacements. In 2006, approximately 800,000 individuals underwent a hip replacement or knee replacement, and nearly 40% of them went on to receive rehabilitation care in either a skilled nursing facility (SNF) or an inpatient rehabilitation facility (IRF).1,2 SNFs and IRFs often serve roughly similar patients and are seen as potential substitutes for one another. One of the main differences between SNFs and IRFs is that IRF care includes a higher level of medical supervision under the direction of an on-site physician. IRFs also provide a more intense level of daily therapy over a shorter period of time for patients who can tolerate 3 or more hours of physical and/or occupational therapy per day as required by regulation.

As the demand of joint replacement rehabilitation has increased, policy makers and health plans have expressed concerns about the relative cost efficiency of SNF and IRF care. There has been lengthy debate as to which setting, SNF or IRF, is more cost-effective or payment-efficient in treating joint replacement patients (i.e., lower cost or payment while achieving similar outcomes). This debate intensified in 2004 with the gradual implementation of the 75% rule (now, 60% rule),3–5 which significantly limited the types of joint replacement patients who could be admitted to an IRF. Implicit in the Medicare ruling was the assumption that joint replacement patients could be treated in SNFs less expensively without diminishing outcomes. IRF advocates argue that this assumption fails to consider IRFs’ advantage in discharging patients in a much shorter time. A shorter length of stay (LOS), they argue, not only represents less utilization of health care resources but also enables patients to resume an independent lifestyle more quickly and reduces the need for continued family support during the recovery period.6

One reason for the lack of research on this issue is that the 2 settings use different patient assessment tools (Inpatient Rehabilitation Facility–Patient Assessment Instrument, known as IRF-PAI in IRFs, and Minimum Data Set, known as MDS in SNFs) that limit the ability to compare outcomes between the 2 settings. Scores obtained by both tools cannot be compared directly because they use different items and scales. In the absence of a reliable crosswalk between the 2 instruments, previous research used peripheral outcome measures, such as mortality rates or rehospitalizations.7 Such measures are not as relevant as those that measure improvements in patient functional status—the key focus of postacute rehabilitative care. Therefore, current research is limited mainly to a direct comparison of cost/payment between the 2 settings without considering differences in patient severity and functional status outcomes.

This study, using a common functional assessment instrument in both settings, evaluated the efficiency of care, defined as functional improvement achieved for a given amount of input(s) (i.e., payment and LOS) for hip and knee replacement patients receiving rehabilitation care in either SNFs or IRFs. This study considered patient LOS as a distinct input apart from payment and evaluated the overall efficiency of care by considering both payment and length of stay concurrently. This article answers 2 main questions: 1) Which setting, SNF or IRF, treats joint replacement patients more efficiently? 2) What factors influence the efficiency with which SNFs and IRFs provide rehabilitation?

sec.title: Design
sec.p: This study used a prospective multisite observational cohort design to evaluate the relative efficiency of SNF- and IRF-level care for joint replacement rehabilitation patients.

sec.title: Setting and Participants
sec.p: Twenty-two facilities, 11 SNFs and 11 IRFs across the nation, originally participated in this study. Three free-standing SNFs were excluded from the sample because of data completeness and quality issues. We also excluded 1 hospital-based SNF because Medicare payment based on SNF “resource utilization groups” (RUGs) is a poor surrogate for actual costs in hospital-based SNFs.8 A geographically diverse group of 11 IRFs and 7 free-standing SNFs were included in the final sample. At least 1 SNF and 1 IRF were recruited from each of 4 census regions. The recruitment of facilities was described in detail in DeJong et al.9

The study included 948 knee replacement patients (247 from SNFs and 701 from IRFs) and 618 hip replacement patients (137 from SNFs and 481 from IRFs) enrolled consecutively upon admission to a SNF or an IRF between February 2006 and February 2007. It was the recommendation of the study’s multi-stakeholder advisory panel that we not try recruiting patients from acute care for a large variety of design, logistical, cost, and timing issues. We thus did not have to cope with refusal rates or address differences that might otherwise occur between participants and nonparticipants. We did not address how patients got from acute to post–acute care and how this might affect patient differences. To be included in this study, patients had to be 1) 21 years of age or older, 2) admitted pursuant to hip or knee replacement, and 3) admitted from any source. We excluded patients who 1) had a bilateral procedure or 2) had a hip replacement subsequent to a hip fracture. We excluded 2 patients with a LOS of 52 days or more (both were SNF patients) because their LOS was markedly different from the LOS of other SNF patients; they accounted for only 0.5% of SNF patients.

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: The study collected data on 1) patient characteristics, including severity of illness, comorbidities, and functional status, and 2) facility characteristics. Patient data were obtained from medical records and point-of-care documentation and were collected by a clinical practice team that consisted of each site’s site director and lead clinicians, including physicians, physical therapists, occupational therapists, nurses, and case managers. Data on facility characteristics were obtained by a structured questionnaire that was sent to each study facility site director to collect information such as geographic location, profit status, bed size, annual patient volume, occupancy rates, physician and pharmacy services, payer mix, staff ratios, and presence of beds dedicated to joint replacement rehabilitation.

We used the functional independence measure (FIM) to assess functional status of patients in both settings in keeping with advice rendered by the study’s Policy Advisory Panel representing all key stakeholder groups (e.g., payers, providers, researchers, and consumers). The panel recommended using the FIM over other instruments (e.g., Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Arthritis Index [WOMAC]) because the FIM was already used in 1 of the 2 settings, was embedded in the IRF payment system, would help determine if there were any underlying cognitive issues among older patients, and would not require patient self-report and therefore avert sample attrition.

Because SNFs do not use FIM routinely whereas IRFs do, it was essential to ensure that all sites interpreted and administered the FIM in the same manner. Thus, all participating clinical staff completed a 3-day training session provided by a national FIM training organization and were required to score 100% on an exam that tested their knowledge of the tool and its use. We monitored FIM data for unusual values and systematic up-coding or down-coding behaviors at local facilities.

sec.title: Inputs
sec.p: We examined 2 inputs: payment and length of stay. Instead of obtaining payment information from medical billing, we calculated Medicare payment for IRF patients using case-mix group (CMG) and severity tier, as well as payment for SNF patients using RUGs and number of SNF days. IRF payment was determined by the CMG and the severity tier that patients were classified into upon admission to IRFs.10 Payment for SNF patients was calculated by summing all payments in different RUGs (sum for each patient of daily RUG payment multiplied by days categorized into that RUG).11 In this study, we used 2006 base payment rates for both settings. The use of unadjusted payment did not account for adjustments normally made, such as rural/urban location, teaching status, and other factors. Thus, payment rates used were geographically neutral and allowed comparisons to be made using a “level playing field.”

sec.title: Output
sec.p: Output was defined as the improvement in motor FIM score. This was calculated by subtracting motor FIM score upon admission from motor FIM score upon discharge. Motor FIM gain served as the study’s main outcome variable because the motor portion of the FIM was more aligned with the goals associated with joint replacement rehabilitation upon discharge. The FIM is an industry-standard patient assessment tool that is also used by the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) in its case-mix adjustment method for IRF payment. Our use of the FIM also follows the recommendation of the study’s multi-stakeholder Policy Advisory Panel.

The 18-item FIM instrument measures independent performance in self-care, sphincter control, transfers, locomotion, communication, and social cognition.12 The instrument consists of 2 subscales, Motor FIM (13 items) and Cognitive FIM (5 items). Each item was rated by clinicians at each site using a 7-point scale. By adding points for each item, the possible total score ranges from 18 (lowest) to 126 (highest) level of independence.

sec.title: Efficiency
sec.p: Efficiency in this study was defined as points of the motor FIM score that could be obtained for a given amount of payment, LOS, or combination of payment and LOS. We measured at the individual patient level to indicate how efficiently a given patient was treated in a SNF or an IRF. Payment efficiency was defined as motor FIM gain per $1000 payment. Length-of-stay efficiency was defined as motor FIM gain per day (motor FIM gain divided by length of stay). The third measure of efficiency, multi-input efficiency, took both payment and length of stay into account rather than only the calculation of a single ratio. Stochastic frontier analysis (SFA) was applied to produce the efficiency score that took into account both inputs simultaneously. SFA uses an indirect approach to measure efficiency, controlling for exogenous influences on output and interpreting unexplained variation in part from inefficient behavior.13 In this study, SFA begins with the estimation model as

where i indicates the ith individual patient, νi is statistical noise, and µi is a nonnegative inefficiency component. Together, they constitute the residual, which is the deviation between observed and fitted values. The SFA efficiency score is calculated as 1 – µi. It ranges from 0 (inefficiency) to 1 (efficiency).
Independent variables consisted of patient variables (e.g., age, gender) and facility variables (e.g., setting, bed size).

The key explanatory variables in this study are setting variables, using a dummy variable indicating patients receiving rehabilitation care from SNF or IRF. In addition, we further classified each setting using setting volume of patients by annual volume of joint replacement patients served in 2006: low (20– 45 patients), medium (100–183 patients), high (272–347 patients), and very high volume (604–606 patients). We selected the volume ranges based on very clear cut-points in facility volumes observed among participating facilities. As a result, the participating facilities included 3 low-volume facilities (all SNFs), 8 medium-volume facilities (3 SNFs and 5 IRFs), 5 high-volume facilities (1 SNF and 4 IRFs), and 2 very high-volume facilities (both IRFs).

The CMG as defined in the IRF payment system was another key explanatory variable representing the case mix of patients in each setting. As shown in Table 1, the CMGs were determined by a patient’s motor FIM score upon admission and his or her age. CMG 801 is the least functionally limited group; CMG 806 is the most functionally limited group. The IRF prospective payment system further stratifies each CMG into 4 severity tiers based on the presence of select comorbidities: tier 0 (none on list of comorbidities), tier 3 (moderately severe), tier 2 (more severe), and tier 1 (most severe). Although not used in the SNF payment system, we applied the same CMG method to SNF patients by using each patient’s admission motor FIM, age, and comorbidities.

caption.p: Definition of CMGs for Joint Replacement

fn.p: CMG, case-mix group; FIM, functional independence measure; NA, not applicable.

sec.p: In addition, we used the Comprehensive Severity Index (CSI) as our main measure of illness severity and acuity upon admission to rehabilitation care settings. The CSI uses 2200 potential indicators, weighted and clustered into more than 5500 disease-specific criteria sets. The CSI indicators include disease-specific signs, symptoms, and physical findings along with psychological parameters and produce a single overall score.14–16 The CSI score is a continuous measure from 0 (least severe) to any positive integer (higher scores indicate greater severity of illness).
We also included “onset days” (days from surgery to onset of rehabilitation) to measure how quickly patients receive rehabilitation care after surgery.

sec.title: Data Analyses
sec.p: We analyzed knee replacement patients and hip replacement patients separately. We used descriptive, bivariate, and multivariate analyses to examine efficiency measures and how facility and patient characteristics related to efficiency. We compared patient characteristics, severity, and case mix using the t test for continuous variables and the χ2 test for category variables. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) and t test were used to compare the inputs, motor FIM gains, and efficiencies across 6 types of facilities and between SNFs and IRFs.

One challenge when comparing payment and efficiency between SNFs and IRFs is the difference in severity of patients served in the 2 settings. Previous studies have shown that IRF patients generally had lower admission motor FIM score and more complications than did SNF patients.9,17 The literature indicated that IRF patients were more likely to be in higher CMG groups and more severe tiers that have higher payment. In this study, we used propensity score matching (PSM) to case-mix adjust the comparison between SNF and IRF patients. PSM involves selecting a subgroup from IRF patients in which the distribution of observed variables, including patient characteristics, admission status, CMG, and tier in this study, is as similar as possible to the distribution in SNF patients. PSM uses a logit model to estimate a propensity score for each patient (i.e., the predicted probability of group membership in SNF or IRF based on these variables). SNF patients and IRF patients are matched according to their propensity scores, and then only the matched patients are compared. In this study, we used 1-to-1 nearest neighbor within caliper match to select those closely matched pairs (the difference of PSM scores of 2 cases is smaller than 0.10) and to balance the distributions of SNF and IRF patients. Because of the 1-to-1 match, some cases that could be matched may be excluded if the other group does not have enough similar cases for match. We also conducted 1-to-N match to see how many cases are unmatched between SNFs and IRFs.

Although PSM is useful to reduce bias due to patient baseline characteristics, it has several limitations.18 This technique may yield over- or underestimates if the 2 groups do not have substantial overlaps. The 1-to-1 match can also alter the composition of a sample (e.g., mix of CMG groups in this study), and the results of comparison of group means should be interpreted with caution. To avoid risks brought by solely relying on PSM, we used multivariate models to evaluate the difference between settings in the overall efficiency of treating patients, controlling for patient characteristics.

In this study, we constructed 2 tobit models because SFA efficiency score is a limited dependent variable, which ranges from 0 to 1. Model 1 used the SNF/IRF variable, and model 2 further subdivided SNF/IRF by volume. We did not include the effect of individual facility in models given the high overlap between the individual facility variables and facility types subcategorized by volume. For example, there is only 1 high-volume SNF in this study. Patient characteristics, case mix, and severity of illness were also included as independent variables. We reran the regressions with a random effects model to observe the changes in coefficients and significance of explanatory variables after controlling the site effects in hierarchical models.

sec.title: Sample Description
sec.p: Table 2 presents patient characteristics, including demographics, admission and discharge status, CMG, and tier upon admission, by type of facility where they received care. Joint replacement patients typically were women in their early 70s, and IRF patients were younger than SNF patients. In general, IRF patients had a more severe medical and functional profile upon admission than did SNF patients. IRF patients had higher admission CSI scores, lower admission motor and cognitive FIM scores, and higher pain scores at admission, and they were less likely to fall into CMG 801–802, the least severe CMGs. IRF joint replacement patients were more likely to have a tier 1 or tier 2 comorbidity compared to SNF patients. IRF patients were discharged with lower motor FIM scores but achieved larger gains in motor FIM than did SNF patients.

caption.p: Patient Characteristics by Replacement Type and Setting

fn.p: IRF, inpatient rehabilitation facility; SNF, skilled nursing facility; HMO, health maintenance organization; CSI, Comprehensive Severity Index; BMI, body mass index; FIM, functional independence measure; CMG, case-mix group.

sec.title: Efficiency Analyses
sec.p: Table 3 presents the comparison of inputs, outputs, and efficiencies across subcategories of settings as well as direct comparison between SNF and IRF. Direct comparison showed that SNF patients took a longer time and gained less FIM but with less payment than IRF patients; SNF patients received more efficient treatment than IRF patients did in terms of payment. IRF patients were more length-of-stay efficient than SNF patients. When we take into account both inputs (i.e., SFA efficiency), knee replacement patients treated in IRFs scored higher than SNF patients. There was no significant difference in SFA efficiency between SNF and IRF among hip replacement patients.

caption.p: Comparison of Inputs, Outputs, and Efficiency Measures by Volume of Joint Replacement Patients within SNFs and IRFs

fn.p: IRF, inpatient rehabilitation facility; SNF, skilled nursing facility; LOS, length of stay; FIM, functional independence measure; SFA, stochastic frontier analysis.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Six-groups comparison refers to the analysis of variance for low-volume SNFs, medium-volume SNFs, high-volume SNFs, medium-volume IRFs, high-volume IRFs, and very high-volume IRFs.

fn.label: b
fn.p: IRF/SNF comparison refers to the comparison between SNF total and IRF total.
P < 0.05 and ***P < 0.001, indicating the significance of comparison within SNFs or IRFs by volume.

sec.p: Efficiency comparison across volume subcategories of settings showed large variance within each type of setting. We found significant differences across IRFs with different patient volumes in all inputs, output, and efficiency measures for both hip and knee replacement. Within SNFs, knee replacement patients received more efficient treatment in facilities with medium volume of patients than the other 2 volume subgroups of SNFs. There were no significant differences found in SNF hip replacement patients.

We further compared 3 efficiency measures between SNF and IRF patients in 6 CMG groups (see Figure 1). In all 6 CMG groups, SNF patients were treated more efficiently in terms of payment than IRF patients, whereas IRF patients were treated more efficiently in terms of length of stay. However, SFA efficiency, which took into account both inputs, showed mixed results across CMG groups. For both SNF and IRF patients, SFA efficiency scores showed an inverted U relation with CMG groups and reached the highest number in CMG 804. SNF patients achieved higher or similar efficiency in CMG 802, 803, and 804 than IRF patients did. IRF patients were treated more efficiently than SNF patients in lowest groups, CMG 801, or highest groups, CMG 805 and 806.

caption.p: Efficiency scores across case-mix groups (CMGs) by setting. IRF, inpatient rehabilitation facility; SNF, skilled nursing facility; LOS, length of stay; SFA, stochastic frontier analysis.

sec.title: PSM Results
sec.p: Table 4 shows the results of adjusted comparisons between SNF and IRF patients in terms of characteristics, admission and discharge status, inputs, output, and efficiencies after propensity score matching. When using 1-to-1 matching, 149 pairs of knee replacement and 79 pairs of hip replacement patients were matched. When using 1-to-N match, only 9 SNF and 13 IRF knee replacement patients and 2 SNF and 8 IRF hip replacement patients were excluded.

caption.p: Comparison of Patient Characteristics, Inputs, Outputs, and Efficiencies after Propensity Score Matching between SNF and IRF Patients

fn.p: IRF, inpatient rehabilitation facility; SNF, skilled nursing facility; HMO, health maintenance organization; CSI, Comprehensive Severity Index; BMI, body mass index; FIM, functional independence measure; CMG, case-mix group; LOS, length of stay; SFA, stochastic frontier analysis.

sec.p: After PSM, 1-to-1 matched SNF and IRF patients showed high similarity in characteristics, severity, and case mix. Compared to unadjusted results, we found similar significant differences in payment, LOS, payment efficiency, and LOS efficiency. However, both groups of patients achieved similar motor FIM gains. After adjustment, we found that SNF and IRF are not different in SFA efficiency for knee replacement, but SNFs are more SFA efficient than IRFs in treating hip replacement patients.

sec.title: Regression Results
sec.p: Table 5 presents the results of regression analyses. The dependent variable is SFA efficiency score. Controlling for patient characteristics, severity, and case mix, the setting (SNF/IRF) where patients received treatment is not significant in predicting the efficiency score of knee replacement patients. However, hip replacement patients were more efficiently treated in SNFs than IRFs by 4.3 percentage points. Model 2 confirmed the ANOVA results concerning the variance within SNF and IRF. It showed that both hip and knee replacement patients had more efficient treatment in medium-volume and very high-volume facilities than low- or high-volume facilities.

caption.p: Results of Tobit Regression and Random Effects Models Predicting SFA Efficiency Score

fn.p: In model 1, the reference group of SNF is IRF; we set CMG 802 and tier 0 as the reference groups of CMGs and tiers. In model 2, medium-volume IRF was the reference group for all other types of facility. We selected these reference groups because they contained more cases. IRF, inpatient rehabilitation facility; SNF, skilled nursing facility; HMO, health maintenance organization; CSI, Comprehensive Severity Index; BMI, body mass index; CMG, case-mix group.

sec.p: One interesting finding is the significant, negative effect of onset days on the efficiency of treatment in all models. The finding indicates that regardless of care setting, the earlier joint replacement patients received rehabilitation care, the more efficient their treatment.

The results of random effects hierarchical models showed similar effects of explanatory variables except for facility-type variables. In all 4 models, facility-type variables (setting by volume) became insignificant after site effects were taken into account. Given the overlap between individual sites and facility type by volume, it is not surprising to see the effects of facility-type change using random effects models.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: By using a uniform method to assess functional status across SNFs and IRFs, this study was able to evaluate both payment and length-of-stay efficiency of knee and hip replacement patients in improving their functional status in SNF and IRF. We found that SNF patients were treated more efficiently in terms of payment, whereas IRF patients were treated more efficiently in terms of length of stay. Study results remain inconclusive as to which setting, SNF or IRF, provides more efficient joint replacement rehabilitation based on functional gains when taking into account both inputs, payment and length of stay, simultaneously.

Findings of this study suggest 3 main conclusions. First, SNF patients achieved more functional improvement for a given amount of total payment, and IRF patients achieved more functional improvement for a given length of stay. When considering both inputs together (i.e., payment and length of stay), SNF and IRF patients demonstrated similar efficiencies. From a policy perspective, the findings support the often-made presumption that joint replacement patients can achieve similar functional outcomes with less payment in SNFs. From a consumer perspective, the findings support the observation that joint replacement patients can achieve similar functional gains in less time in IRFs and thus can return to home and community life earlier.

Second, great variation existed within IRFs and SNFs in terms of both inputs and output. Low-volume facilities had the worst efficiencies, and medium-volume facilities—among both SNFs and IRFs—had the highest efficiencies. This finding may suggest that low-volume facilities are not as likely to achieve the economies of scale and proficiency needed to produce good outcomes. The finding also suggests that CMS and health plans might consider setting a minimum threshold for the number of joint replacement patients served in any one facility—although one should not overgeneralize from this finding because it stems from a limited set of facilities. Because a large number of SNFs serve fewer than 10 joint replacement patients annually,19 there may be considerable room for health plans to improve the efficiency of rehabilitation care in SNFs by excluding facilities that do not serve a certain minimum number of joint replacement patients. This might raise the issue of patient accessibility, especially in rural areas, and therefore needs to be balanced. On the basis of the findings of this study, we are unable to specify, however, the exact volume below which facilities should be excluded.

Third, number of days from surgery to rehabilitation admission is associated with the efficiency of treatment for patients. Regardless of setting, starting rehabilitation earlier leads to more efficient treatment (i.e., greater functional improvement for a given payment or length of stay). This finding is consistent with previous studies that observed an association between onset days and functional outcomes among joint replacement patients.9,20 This suggests that rehabilitation care for joint replacement patients should, from an efficiency perspective, start as early as possible after discharge from acute care settings.

Unlike previous efficiency studies that used facility as the unit of analysis, this study used patient-level data by evaluating how efficiently an individual patient was treated in a given setting and thereby evaluating overall SNF and IRF efficiency. Patient-level analysis allowed us to explore 3 issues. First, it solved the small-numbers problem (i.e., too few facilities to perform reliable efficiency analysis at the individual facility level).21 Second, it allowed us to detect the influence of patient characteristics that are often masked in facility-level analysis. And third, it enabled us to investigate the efficiency difference across case-mix groups. Several limitations of this study should be noted. First, caution is required in generalizing to all SNFs and IRFs. Although the study captured geographic diversity, facility participation was voluntary and thus presents potential selection effects. Facilities included in this study generally represented larger urban facilities. Both smaller SNFs and IRFs, particularly smaller IRF units, were underrepresented. Moreover, although the number of participating facilities is much larger than previous studies, it is still not enough to uncover effects of individual facility characteristics apart from facility volume. For example, when controlling for individual site effects, the effect of high-volume SNF could not be observed as we discussed in the methods.

Second, although this analysis included 1566 patients, making it one of the largest joint replacement rehabilitation studies using primary data collection, the sample size was still not large enough to adequately represent every subgroup. When we tried to adjust outcomes for case mix by using CMG groups and tiers, some cells had only a few patients. For example, there were only 6 knee replacement patients in SNF CMG 803, which explains its large confidence interval. Small numbers within a CMG carry the risk of having a handful of cases that can flip overall results and thus undermine the stability of the results. Moreover, using PSM resulted in considerable sample attrition, making the overlap group small relative to the original sample. This limits the ability to generalize from the PSM analysis.

Third, despite its use in IRFs as a standard assessment tool, the FIM is a generic assessment tool and not a condition-specific tool designed to capture more nuanced changes in joint replacement functional recovery as the WOMAC is designed to do.22

Fourth, this article addresses only efficiency upon discharge from SNFs or IRFs; it does not address longer term outcomes and associated inputs such as additional rehabilitation services used. Literature suggests that many patients receive considerable amounts of additional therapy after discharge from their initial rehabilitation setting. Hence, the evaluation of rehabilitation efficiency may change when considering longer term outcomes and use of additional therapy.17 Future studies should also examine efficiency over an entire episode of care, not only the initial setting as in this study.

This study attempted to disentangle some of the issues about which setting (SNF or IRF) is more efficient. One’s definition of efficiency depends in part on one’s preference between cost and time. Current policy debate emphasizes payment efficiency, a perspective not necessarily shared by the patient who may favor time, unless he or she is also liable for payment. Third-party payment masks consumer preferences by removing from the patient the need to make time and payment tradeoffs relative to the functional gains that can be made. The question remains as to whose voice should be heard more—the taxpayer or the patient. When we consider the 2 inputs together, the advantage of either setting is not clear-cut. A simple dichotomous comparison between SNF and IRF appears somewhat artificial. The findings of this study suggest that choice of rehabilitation care setting should also take into account other important factors such as facility volume, onset days, case mix, and possibly patient preference. Policy makers, payers, and rehabilitation professionals should include outcome judgments and payment criteria that incorporate patients’ inputs.
